Quote: I bring you with reverent handsThe books of my numberless dreams.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: I know that I shall meet my fate somewhere among the clouds above; those that I fight I do not hate, those that I guard I do not love.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Author: W.B. Yeats

Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: I said: 'A line will take us hours maybe;Yet if it does not seem a moment's thought,Our stitching and unstitching has been naught.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: I sat, a solitary man,In a crowded London shop,An open book and empty cupOn the marble table-top.While on the shop and street I gazedMy body of a sudden blazed;And twenty minutes more or lessIt seemed, so great my happiness,That I was blessed and could bless.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: I spit into the face of Time That has transfigured me.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: I spit into the face of Time That has transfigured me.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: It is so many years before one can believe enough in what one feels even to know what the feeling is.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: It is so many years before one can believe enough in what one feels even to know what the feeling is.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: People who lean on logic and philosophy and rational exposition end by starving the best part of the mind.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: THOUGH you are in your shining days,Voices among the crowdAnd new friends busy with your praise,Be not unkind or proud,But think about old friends the most:Time's bitter flood will rise,Your beauty perish and be lostFor all eyes but these eyes.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: To long a sacrifice can make a stone of a heart.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: What can be explained is not poetry.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: What can be explained is not poetry.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: When you are old and grey and full of sleep And nodding by the fire, take down this book, And slowly read, and dream of the soft look Your eyes had once, and of their shadows deep.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: Wine enters through the mouth,Love, the eyes.I raise the glass to my mouth,I look at you,I sigh.
Author: W.B. Yeats

Quote: A poet is, before anything else, a person who is passionately in love with language.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: All the rest is silenceOn the other side of the wall;And the silence ripeness,And the ripeness all.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: All the rest is silenceOn the other side of the wall;And the silence ripeness,And the ripeness all.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: And each in the cell of himself is almost convinced of his freedom.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: And each in the cell of himself is almost convinced of his freedom.

Quote: Base words are uttered only by the baseAnd can for such at once be understood;But noble platitudes — ah, there's a caseWhere the most careful scrutiny is neededTo tell a voice that's genuinely goodFrom one that's base but merely has succeeded.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Clear, unscalable, aheadRise the Mountains of Instead,From whose cold, cascading streamsNone may drink except in dreams.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Every poet has his dream reader: mine keeps a look out for curious prosodic fauna like bacchics and choriambs.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Happy the hare at morning, for she cannot readThe hunter's waking thoughts.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: He was my North, my South, my East and West,My working week and my Sunday rest,My noon, my midnight, my talk, my song;I thought that love would last forever: I was wrong.
Author: W.H. Auden

Author: W.H. Auden

Author: W.H. Auden

Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: If you want romance, fuck a journalist.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: In the eyes of others a man is a poet if he has written one good poem. In his own he is only a poet at the moment when he is making his last revision to a new poem. The moment before, he was still only a potential poet; the moment after, he is a man who has ceased to write poetry, perhaps forever.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: In the prison of his daysTeach the free man how to praise.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Language is the mother, not the handmaiden, of thought; words will tell you things you never thought or felt before.
Author: W.H. Auden

Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: O stand, stand at the window As the tears scald and start;You shall love your crooked neighbour With your crooked heart.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Poetry makes nothing happen.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Poetry makes nothing happen.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Poetry might be defined as the clear expression of mixed feelings.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Say this city has ten million souls,Some are living in mansions, some are living in holes:Yet there’s no place for us, my dear, yet there’s no place for us.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: So long as we think of it objectively, time is Fate or Chance, the factor in our lives for which we are not responsible, and about which we can do nothing; but when we begin to think of it subjectively, we feel responsible for our time, and the notion of punctuality arises.
Author: W.H. Auden

Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Some thirty inches from my noseThe frontier of my Person goes,And all the untilled air betweenIs private pagus or demesne.Stranger, unless with bedroom eyesI beckon you to fraternize,Beware of rudely crossing it:I have no gun, but I can spit.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: The element of craftsmanship in poetry is obscured by the fact that all men are taught to speak and most to read and write, while very few men are taught to draw or paint or write music.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: The Ogre does what ogres can,Deeds quite impossible for Man,But one prize is beyond his reach:The Ogre cannot master speech.About a subjugated plain,Among it's desperate and slain,The Ogre stalks with hands on hips,While drivel gushes from his lips.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: The religious definition of truth is not that it is universal but that it is absolute.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: There are good books which are only for adults.There are no good books which are only for children.

Quote: We must love one another or die.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: We would rather be ruined than changedWe would rather die in our dreadThan climb the cross of the momentAnd let our illusions die.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: When words lose their meaning, physical force takes over.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: Without art, we should have no notion of the sacred; without science, we should always worship false gods.
Author: W.H. Auden

Quote: You shall love your crooked neighbour, with your crooked heart.

Quote: A pear should come to the table popped with juice,Ripened in warmth and served in warmth. On termsLike these, autumn beguiles the fatalist.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: A poem is a meteor.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: After the final no there comes a yes / And on that yes the future world depends.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Author: Wallace Stevens

Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: After the leaves have fallen, we returnTo a plain sense of things. It is as ifWe had come to an end of the imagination,Inanimate in an inert savoir.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: Conceptions are artificial. Perceptions are essential.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: I am the truth, since I am part of what is real, but neither more nor less than those around me.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: I do not know which to prefer,The beauty of inflectionsOr the beauty of innuendosThe blackbird whistlingOr just after.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: I placed a jar in Tennessee and round it was upon a hill.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: I placed a jar in Tennessee and round it was upon a hill.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: Let be be finale of seem.The only emperor is the emperor of ice-cream.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: One must read poetry with one's nerves.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: Perhaps the truth depends on a walk around the lake.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: Perhaps the truth depends on a walk around the lake.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: Poetry is an abstraction bloodied.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: Poetry is the scholar's art.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: The exceeding brightness of this early sunMakes me conceive how dark I have become.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: The exceeding brightness of this early sunMakes me conceive how dark I have become.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: The final belief is to believe in a fiction, which you know to be a fiction, there being nothing else. The exquisite truth is to know that it is a fiction and that you believe in it willingly.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: The only emperor is the emperor of ice cream.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: The poem must resist the intelligenceAlmost successfully.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: The way through the worldIs more difficult to find than the way beyond it.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Author: Wallace Stevens

Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: There will never be an endTo this droning of the surf.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: We live in an old chaos of the sun.
Author: Wallace Stevens

Quote: Afoot and light-hearted I take to the open road.Healthy, free, the world before me.The long brown path before me leading me wherever I choose.Henceforth, I ask not good fortune, I myself am good fortune.Henceforth, I whimper no more, postpone no more, need nothing.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: And I or you pocketless of a dime, may purchase the pick of the earth.
Author: Walt Whitman

Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: Every moment of light and dark is a miracle.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: For we cannot tarry here,We must march my darlings, we must bear the brunt of danger,We, the youthful sinewy races, all the rest on us depend, Pioneers! O pioneers!
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: Here the frailest leaves of me and yet my strongest lasting, Here I shade and hide my thoughts, I myself do not expose them, And yet they expose me more than all my other poems.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: I act as the tongue of you,... tied in your mouth.... in mine it begins to be loosened.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: I act as the tongue of you,... tied in your mouth.... in mine it begins to be loosened.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: I am larger, better than I thought; I did not know I held so much goodness.All seems beautiful to me.Whoever denies me, it shall not trouble me;	Whoever accepts me, he or she shall be blessed, and shall bless me.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: I believe in the flesh and the appetites; Seeing, hearing, feeling, are miracles, and each part and tag of me is a miracle. Divine am I inside and out, and I make holy whatever I touch or am touch’d from;The scent of these arm-pits, aroma finer than prayer; This head more than churches, bibles, and all the creeds.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: I believe in the flesh and the appetites; Seeing, hearing, feeling, are miracles, and each part and tag of me is a miracle. Quote: I bequeath myself to the dirt to grow from the grass I loveIf you want me again look for me under your boot-soles.You will hardly know who I am or what I meanBut I shall be good health to you nonethelessAnd filter and fibre your blood.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: I celebrate myself, and sing myself, And what I assume you shall assume,For every atom belonging to me as good belongs to you.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: I discover myself on the verge of a usual mistake.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: I have said that the soul is not more than the body,And I have said that the body is not more than the soul,And nothing, not God, is greater to one than one's-self is,.
Author: Walt Whitman

Author: Walt Whitman

Author: Walt Whitman

Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: Some people are so much sunshine to the square inch.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: Sometimes with one I love, I fill myself with rage, for fear I effuse unreturn'd love; But now I think there is no unreturn'd love—the pay is certain, one way or another; (I loved a certain person ardently, and my love was not return'd; Yet out of that, I have written these songs.).
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: Songs of myselfClear and sweet is my soul, and clear and sweet is all that is not my soul. Lack one lacks both, and the unseen is proved by the seen, Till that becomes unseen and receives proof in its turn.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: The dirtiest book of all is the expurgated book.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: The dirtiest book of all is the expurgated book.

Quote: The press of my foot to the earth springs a hundred affections,They scorn the best I can do to relate them.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: The untold want, by life and land ne'er granted,Now, Voyager, sail thou forth, to seek and find.
Author: Walt Whitman

Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: This is thy hour O Soul, thy free flight into the wordless, Away from books, away from art, the day erased, the lesson done,Thee fully forth emerging, silent, gazing, pondering the themes thou lovest best. Night, sleep, and the stars.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: TO the States or any one of them, or any city of the States, Resist much, obey little, Once unquestioning obedience, once fully enslaved,Once fully enslaved, no nation, state, city of this earth, ever after-ward resumes its liberty.
Author: Walt Whitman

Quote: What is that you express in your eyes? It seems to me more than all the print I have read in my life.
Author: Walt Whitman

Author: Walter Bagehot

Quote: The greatest pleasure in life is doing what people say you cannot do.
Author: Walter Bagehot

Quote: The reason why so few good books are written is that so few people who can write know anything.
Author: Walter Bagehot

Quote: Death is the sanction of everything the story-teller can tell. He has borrowed his authority from death.
Author: Walter Benjamin

Quote: Every passion borders on the chaotic, but the collector's passion borders on the chaos of memories.
Author: Walter Benjamin

Quote: Genuine polemics approach a book as lovingly as a cannibal spices a baby.
Author: Walter Benjamin

Quote: Genuine polemics approach a book as lovingly as a cannibal spices a baby.
Author: Walter Benjamin

Author: Walter Benjamin

Author: Walter Benjamin

Author: Walter Isaacson

Author: Walter Scott

Author: Walter Scott

Author: Walter Scott

Quote: Make peace with silence, and remind yourself that it is in this space that you'll come to remember your spirit. When you're able to transcend an aversion to silence, you'll also transcend many other miseries. And it is in this silence that the remembrance of God will be activated.
Author: Wayne W. Dyer

Quote: Not only do you become what you think about, but the world also becomes what you think about. Those who think that the world is a dark place are blind to the light that might illuminate their lives. Those who see the light of the world view the dark spots as merely potential light.
Author: Wayne W. Dyer

Quote: Passion is a feeling that tells you: this is the right thing to do. Nothing can stand in my way. It doesn't matter what anyone else says. This feeling is so good that it cannot be ignored. I'm going to follow my bliss and act upon this glorious sensation of joy.
Author: Wayne W. Dyer

Quote: Remember, purpose is about giving...All you can do with your life is to give it away in the service of others.
Author: Wayne W. Dyer

Quote: When you judge another, you do not define them, you define yourself.
Author: Wayne W. Dyer

Quote: You can't expect to draw people into your life who are kind, confident, and generous if you're thinking and acting in cruel, weak, and selfish ways. You must be what it is that you're seeking— that is, you need to put forth what you want to attract.
Author: Wayne W. Dyer

Author: William Blake

Quote: I must create a system, or be enslaved by another man's. I will not reason and compare: my business is to create.
Author: William Blake

Quote: If a thing loves, it is infinite.

Quote: The tree which moves some to tears of joy is in the eyes of others only a green thing that stands in the way. Some see nature all ridicule and deformity... and some scarce see nature at all. But to the eyes of the man of imagination, nature is imagination itself.
Author: William Blake

Author: William Blake

Quote: And so I told myself to take that one. Because Father said clocks slay time. He said time is dead as long as it is being clicked off by little wheels; only when the clock stops does time come to life. The hands were extended, slightly off the horizontal at a faint angle, like a gull tilting into the wind.
Author: William Faulkner

Author: William Faulkner

Quote: Read, read, read. Read everything - trash, classics, good and bad, and see how they do it. Just like a carpenter who works as an apprentice and studies the master. Read! You'll absorb it.Then write. If it's good, you'll find out. If it's not, throw it out of the window.
Author: William Faulkner

Author: William Faulkner

Quote: She was bored. She loved, had capacity to love, for love, to give and accept love. Only she tried twice and failed twice to find somebody not just strong enough to deserve it, earn it, match it, but even brave enough to accept it.
Author: William Faulkner

Author: William Faulkner

Author: William Faulkner

Quote: Time, the spaces of light and dark, had long since lost orderliness.
Author: William Faulkner

Quote: When my horse is running good, I don't stop to give him sugar.
Author: William Faulkner

Author: William Faulkner

Quote: You don’t love because: you love despite; not for the virtues, but despite the faults.
Author: William Faulkner

Quote: Time moves in one direction, memory another. We are that strange species that constructs artifacts intended to counter the natural flow of forgetting.
Author: William Gibson

Author: William Gibson

Quote: We must judge the tree by its fruit. The best fruits of the religious experience are the best things history has to offer. Quote: All I want from you is to trust me with what little you can, and grow in loving people around you with the same love I share with you. It's not your job to change them, or to convince them. You are free to love without an agenda.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: All I want from you is to trust me with what little you can, and grow in loving people around you with the same love I share with you. It's not your job to change them, or to convince them. You are free to love without an agenda.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: Did I hear God call me an idiot?
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: Did I hear God call me an idiot?
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: Did I hear God call me an idiot?
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: Each relationship between two persons is absolutely unique. That is why you cannot love two people the same. It simply is not possible. You love each person differently because of who they are and the uniqueness that they draw out of you.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: Even though you can't finally grasp me, guess what? I still want to be known.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: Even though you can't finally grasp me, guess what? I still want to be known.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: Faith does not grow in a house of certainty.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: I suppose that since most of our hurts come through relationships so will our healing, and I know that grace rarely makes sense for those looking in from the outside.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: Life takes a bit of time and a lot of relationship.

Quote: Oh my soul...be prepared for him who knows how to ask questions.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: Relationships are never about power, and one way to avoid the will to power is to choose to limit oneself- to serve.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: So many believe that it is love that grows, but it is the knowing that grows and love simply expands to contain it.
Author: William Paul Young

Quote: So no, I’m not too big on religion...and not very fond of politics or economics either...And why should I be? They are the man-created trinity of terrors that ravages the earth and deceives those I care about. What mental turmoil and anxiety does any human face that is not related to one of those three?
Author: William Paul Young

Author: William Paul Young

Quote: You know, they ask me if I were on a desert island and I knew nobody would ever see what I wrote, would I go on writing. My answer is most emphatically yes. I would go on writing for company. Because I'm creating an imaginary — it's always imaginary — world in which I would like to live.).
Author: William S. Burroughs

Author: William Shakespeare

Quote: O, hereWill I set up my everlasting rest,And shake the yoke of inauspicious starsFrom this world-wearied flesh. Eyes, look your last!Arms, take your last embrace! and, lips, O youThe doors of breath, seal with a righteous kissA dateless bargain to engrossing death!
Author: William Shakespeare

Quote: Success breeds ambition, and our recent achievements are now pushing humankind to set itself even more daring goals. Having secured unprecedented levels of prosperity, health and harmony, and given our past record and our current values, humanity’s next targets are likely to be immortality, happiness and divinity.
Author: Yuval Noah Harari

Quote: This is the paradox of historical knowledge. Knowledge that does not change behaviour is useless. But knowledge that changes behaviour quickly loses its relevance.

Quote: We believe in a particular order not because it is objectively true, but because believing in it enables us to cooperate effectively and forge a better society. Author: Yuval Noah Harari
